userreviews.userReview: Sequels are something I attribute to movies and video games but now it seems that this trend is bleeding over into comics. Usually a comic book is marked by each writer's take on the story and characters within specific arcs that are then referenced by other writers down the line. With Marvel's reboot we see Uncanny X-force return to the shelves this time headed by Sam Humphries and I was shocked when I saw that Psylocke was on the front cover.If you've read Remender's stellar run on this series or the reviews I've written you'll know that the series came to a definitive end where all story lines were wrapped up neatly (except for that whole 3 Fantomex business). This includes the characters such as Psylocke who goes through a lot of emotional trauma and the idea that she would jump into the skin tight black suit is simply silly.Humphries adds other boring characters to the mix until we get what is effectively a joke X-force team. Puck? Really? The writing also makes me roll my eyes inputting a black dash symbolizing a swear does not make the writing gritty it just makes the reader annoyed. I couldn't even tell you the plot since it was simply bad. Obviously Marvel wanted to get a money grab through nostalgia but readers aren't that desperate. If you want good X-force stories just re-read the old ones.

This is just bad. Really, really bad. Coming on the heels of Remender's amazing run does not help things, nor does unfocused writing or bad artwork, both of which plague this title. So unfair to these characters...
Ummm... what?

Es lectura con el piloto automático. No me dice nada.. ni la primera parte con el trío Fantomex y Psylocke, ni todo este rollo de los revenants. Totalmente prescindible y me jode porqué compre el primer tomo de Panini, pero lo voy a dejar mas que descolgado, si es que algún día continúan publicando esto.

Bishop's war with the revenants is all well and good, but obviously I prefer the half of this where the clone superthieves and the psychic ninja are sorting out their complicated four-way relationship through the media of fighting and champagne.
Was okay, and not as bad as everyone seems to make this out to be. The Revenant Story could be interesting....may pick up next volume.

For the second volume of this awesome series, this is not quite good as the first one.For the story itself is quite good but for the Fantomex arc is really confusing for me, because i thought that it's a full romance story with a bit of action on the side and turns out it was more than that by making a villain (Weapon XIII) appear out of nowhere.Still, it's very refreshing to see more side of Psylock being fleshed out in the arc and the appearance of Fantomelle (I've been waiting for her to show up with Spiral in Vol.1) kicking ass is a nice thing to see and also the good artwork by Adrian Alphona makes the book enjoyable to read.
Good follow up and interesting conclusion to the Psylocke love triangle. Cliffhangered and looking forward to volume 3.
What the &$#@?

I enjoyed the first volume of Sam Humphries' X-Force run, but this installment fell apart for me. It started with a three-issue arc where Psylocke heads to Madripoor to settle some unfinished business with the Fantomexes. (Fantomex is her former lover, who has now been split into three separate cloned bodies, each with different elements of its personality, leaving her unsure who she really loves. It's confusing, but hey, X-men.)This arc starts with a little humor at least, with a nice self-referential note on how Psylocke's image has changed over the years, from nice, British Betsy Braddock in a pink bathrobe to a leggy, Japanese ninja in a bathing suit. But the love triangle that develops is pretty silly, and it only gets shakier as the issues proceed. It ends up offering a bit of closure that I never needed in the first place.After that we go back to the main storyline from the first volume: Bishop has returned from the future infected by some psychic demon ghost. It's now spreading through L.A., and it even overwhelms our heroes, unleashing their revenants (the evil alter egos that lurk in all of us) onto the world. Again, there are some nice gag lines here, notably with Puck, but a pretty dire situation is handled too easily, without much dramatic interest or sense of risk. The volume even ends on a cliffhanger, after a final issue that seems rushed and overcompressed.I like some of the dialogue here, but the plotting seems unfocused and the ultimate threat ends up being something we've seen before. I wish it had gone in a different direction, showing more confidence in exploring its own ideas.Read digital issues

I feel like the title of this series doesn't really suit it. This isn't an Uncanny X-Force, but it is a pseudo-team worth watching.The first story here shows us the background between Psylocke and the three Fantomexes, which is an intriguing if slightly baffling tale. I'm not sure if the characterization is exactly right, but it is an unpredictable and enjoyable little romp.We get back to business after that with the second story which brings back an old X-Foe I personally love, and continues the Revenant War story we got going in the first volume. This is a more straight-forward story than the first, and has a fun cliffhanger that makes me want to know what's next very soon.Artistically this volume is a mixed bag. Adrian Alphona's artwork is beautiful, whilst Dalibor Talajic's contributions are fairly bog-standard and unremarkable. Ramon Perez's two issues are disappointingly messy, a far cry from his lovely work on Wolverine and the X-Men.This is still not a shade on the previous UXF, but taken as a separate book, it's worth having a read.

I don't know why I do this to myself. I don't remember liking any X-Force title in the past. I've found Psylocke to be a dodgy character ever since her mind was placed in a ninja's body lo those many years ago. Fantomex irritates more than entertains. Bishop is written poorly more often than well. I love Storm & Spiral. One day someone will write Puck up to his potential, that day has not yet come. I love the Demon Bear from the old New Mutants story line, I can't determine whether this bear is supposed to somehow be that older bear or not. Cassandra Nova is a poorly conceived antagonist whose abilities change wildly from appearance to appearance to suit the whims of the current creator.In short, this volume contains many of the problematic aspects of superhero comics, and very few of their virtues.

I don't know. I thought the Fantomex, three minds, three bodies thing was interesting. I think the demon bear thing is interesting. I think Spiral is interesting. I think Puck is confusing. Probably Bishop is interesting, but I can't tell if that's just unresolved confusion from his heel turn. I'd like to see more of these people. This is the first time I'm using the "spoiler" tag because my most pressing comment deals with the Big Reveal in the last few pages: that the Big Bad is an evil Charles Xavier. The reason I think that's interesting is because it makes at least four X-books where the Big Bad is a different evil Charles Xavier: Uncanny Avengers, Xtreme X-men, X-Men Legacy, and Uncanny X-Force. There's something a little weird about a "new" creative direction in which an idea is repeated with such frequency. What is?

Fantomexi (7-9). Humphries’ lead story is shockingly good, with its believable look at what it means for Phantomex to be split in three, going hand-in-hand with terrific characterization for Betsy and a really fun reveal of the past. This feels like it could have been written by Remender! [8/10]Revenants (10-12). The next couple of issues are unfortunately a big step down, as we get pointless and long fights with revenants (whatever they are!) and evil doppelgängers [5/10]. Only the last issue saves the revenants storyline, thanks to a great focus on Spiral and attractive art [7/10].Overall, this volume is quite uneven, which is unfortunately what I expect of Humphries. Still, it's decently good on average. I do find it frustrating that the story stops rather than actually ending.

Sam Humphries - writerAdrian Alphono & Dalabor Talajic - illustratorsChris Sotomayor & Lee Loughridge - color artistsFirst, see exactly what happened in Paris when Fantomex split into three separate people - all of whom are in love with Psylocke! Then, Bishop is slowly healing from massive psychic trauma, but his mind still seems dominated by insane visions - until X-Force is suddenly attacked by Bishop's "imaginary" revenants! Plus, an extremely old foe returns and all of humanity is in danger!Sam Humphries is doing a very nice job with this collection, the stories are fun, funny, action-packed and keep the reader guessing. The art team does a very nice job as well. Usually I find it distracting when midway through a collection the art switches, but all the artists do a really stellar job in this book.4.5/5 Recommended.

Oh how this book has fallen. The first volume was decent and set up a reasonable tale, but this goes in a new direction that is terribly unsatisfying. I really hate what Humphries does with Psylocke and Fantomex. It undoes so much of the characterization from the last run, and it's just not enjoyable. The second story arc isn't much better. It's disjointed and hardly makes sense. It doesn't give any character enough time to shine. Plus it reintroduces one of my least favorite villains, and in the process undoes a whole bunch of development that they'd been working toward. On top of all that, the art is terrible. The line work is sloppy, the colors are muddy. It does absolutely nothing for me. The last issue in the book is decent, but still not good. I hate to say it, but I can see why this book has been cancelled.

My favorite part of this series is easily the relationship between Betsy and the 3 versions of Phantomex, so I enjoyed this book a lot. it deals with some of the things that happen before the series started. One thing I will say is that this is one of the most "soap opera" comics I have read in a long time. Seriously think about: it's got these weird love triangles and clones and such all running around. It's such a soap opera cliché. (Or a early 90's Spider-Man cliché). If you want to read this book I would suggest you not go into it thinking about Remender's run of the previous series. It just won't measure up. You have to take it as it is.

This was an interesting story, with half revolving around the consequences of Fantomex splitting into three people, and his (their?) relationship with Psylocke; and the other half having to do with Bishop and his weird future spirit double revenant thing. They made an effort to tie that into some existing X-Men plots, but it was... strange. The first half made for interesting reading, and the second half had some good action sequences, so there were good things here, if rather different from each other.

You know what it's like when your lover's three brains are separated into three different bodies, and you start dating one brain, then you break up and start dating another brain, then the brains start dating each other, and it all gets a bit complicated. Well, that's what Psylocke's going through the now. It's X-Men's ability to portray such realistic, identifiable relationships that has kept it loved by a generation into adulthood.Also, Fantomex wears his mask in bed. Eeeeeewwwww!

I really liked the first volume but it all fell apart here. The stuff with Psylocke and Fantomex went on way too long and the second part made less and less sense.In spite of that it was still entertaining? The first volume stands pretty well on its own tho so I still recommend checking that out if nothing else.2.5ETA I bumped my rating up because I think people are exaggerating how bad it is.

I enjoyed the second volume of Uncanny X-force. Sam Humphries is doing a pretty good job with the characterization of Psylocke. Fantomex is certainly the most strange mutant to come along in the marvel universe. If there is a weakness to the book its the artwork it could have been a bit more consistent and this is probably due to the artist changes. A Solid three star graphic novel.

This uses X-Men characters to take a pretty interesting exploration into (bi)sexuality, romance, identity, and more. Mostly I just really like Fantomex, and so 3 Fantomexes (Fantomii?) are better than 1, except when they're not, which is also the point of the story...

Almost a 3.There is some interesting and predictable stuff going on with the revenants.Honestly, it would help if you read the run before Marvel NOW! to get what is going on with Betsy and her unique romance.

While I did kinda like this book Bishop's story (10#-11#) is written and drawn much better then the first and last stories involving Elizabeth and Spiral.The last story was what made it very mediocre for me.
The whole fantomex/psylocke storyline was very meh. But I still really enjoyed this whole series overall (3 volumes and 17 issues in total)
Annoying and bizarre. Skip it.
I didn't care for the flashback to Elizabeth's time in Paris, but the Bishop and revenant story was better (though still not great).
Individual issues on marvel unlimited
I like these characters, and their interactions a good. I just wish the art were stronger. Sorry.
Must get number one to understand the whole story, not bad!

description: Secrets from the future and the past come to haunt Uncanny X-Force! What does Fantomex want from Betsy? What does Betsy want from Cluster? What does cluster want from Fantomex? What does Bishop want from the 21st century? A body count or a good burger? And Los Angeles, lock up your humans: there's a new mutant on the loose!Collecting: Uncanny X-Force 7-12
title:
Uncanny X-Force, Volume 2: Torn and Frayed
      
          (Uncanny X-Force (2013) (Collected Editions) #2)
